data.title: Avudducandu Marrikar Family
data.text:
Sri Lanka Muslim Family Genealogy

Avuducandu Marikar - Family #106

Avuducandu Marikar Hassen (Ossen) Lebbe

Auvuducandu Marikar Hassen (Ossen) Lebbe, a leader of the Muslim community in Sri Lanka, was one of the commissionerâs who drafted the "Muhammadan" Code of 1806, under which the Muslims were governed in respect of their persons and property. According to a census taken in 1824, there were 14,847 Moors or Muhammadans in Colombo (see Ceylon Daily News 20 February, 1953).

Avuducandu Marikar Hassen Lebbe took a very active part in the management of the Colombo Grand Mosque at new Moor Street. Under the sanitary ordinance imposed by the Municipality, the burial grounds adjacent to the Colombo Grand Mosque was ordered to be shut down from 21 October, 1874. In view of this, Hassen Lebbe set out to establsih a new burial grounds for the Muslims. He was assisted by several wealthy "Mathichams" (Managers) of the Mosque.

Funds were raised by this group and an extent of 37 Acres, 3 Roods and 13 Perches of land, depicted in Plan No. 1826 surveyed by S. G. Schneider, was purchased at Maligawatte (Title Deed No. 85, Notary C.H.Ahliph dated November 10, 1890). The land was vested in the Trustee for the burial of the dead bodies of Muslims.

Hassen Lebbeâs sons were, Othman Haji and Abdul Majeed. Hassan Lebbe Marikar Avuducandu Marikar, having been the First Honorary Turkish Consul was succeeded to this position by his son Abdul Majeed, the Second Honorary Turkish Consul..

Consul Abdul Majeed took an active part in the Silver Jubilee celebrations of the Sultan of Turkey in 1900. He also laid the foundation stone of the Hameedia School and the building of Ibrahim bin Ahmedâs shop at Main Street on this day.

He was succeeded as Consul by Mr. Muhammad Macan Markar of Galle who was the Vice Consul for Turkey.

Consul Abdul Majeed had two daughters, Mrs. M.A.C.Muhammad and Mrs. Zofi Abdul Azeez.

Hassen Lebbeâs other son, Othman Haji, and a cousin of his, Shamsi Lebbe Mathar Lebbe (father of M.L.M. Mackeen) succeeded him as trustee of the Maligawatte Muslim burial grounds. On the death of Mathar Lebbe, and, later of Othman Haji, Othman Hajiâs sons, Noordeen and Sulaiman succeeded them in turn.

An unused portion of the Maligawatte Muslim burial ground was acquired by the Government and O.H.M. Sulaiman transferred all the right, title and interest in the trusteeship to the governing body of the Colombo Grand Mosque, New Moor Street, in 1875, on whose behalf the purchase was made.

A plaque at the Maligawatte Muslim burial ground commemorates the name of Hassen Lebbe. A photograph of him was published in the "Olde Ceylon" by John Capper in the year 1877.

It may be of interest to know that there were only two (2) mosques in Colombo in the year 1505 and there were seventeen (17) in 1824.

SL Mahmood Marikar

Mohamed Farook Mahmood has quoted that his father had quoted his paternal ascendants for 4 generations. He has also said that one of the ascendants of the family was sent by the British government to Maldives as a punishment. Abdul Rahman Mahmood owned two shops, one at No 42 Main Street and other, possibly, next door, in The Pettah in Colombo. He was married at the age of 19. Although the family wanted him to marry within the family circle he chose to seek a bride from outside. Mahmood's wife was Ummu Kulthum, daughter of Samsudeen, partner of Muslim Nation, at Deens Road in Maradana, Colombo 10. Two years after his marriage he sold his business and chose to live on his capital which he had earned during his business. He had three daughters and four sons.

Just after his first daughter's marriage his wife Ummu Kulthum passed away. He married again and his other two daughters were also given in marriage thereafter. He then took his last two sons, Mohamed Thaha, who was 16 years of age then, and Srael Mahmood, who was 9 years old, together with his second wife and left Sri Lanka, for Bombay in India.

He passed away a year later, at the age of 42 in Bombay. His second wife also passed away within a short period. His son Mohamed Thaha Mahmood and his younger brother Srael had to survive alone in Bombay. Thaha returned to Sri Lanka when he was 26 years, after living 10 years in Bombay.

Father in law of (daughter of Marhoom Bakir Hassan Galle Fort), (daughter of Najaath Haajiar of Beruwela), (daughter of Fawzy Abdul Cader Galle) and AM Muslih Abdul Cader. Janaza will leave from 39 Bhathiya Mawatha, Kalubowila, at 4.00 pm, today, (28/08/2019) to Dehiwela Muhiyadeen Jumma Masjid.

A Tribute Issue No. 19th of OUR FAMILY NEWSLETTER.

In this Special 19th Issue, Naseema Haniffa Foundation pays tribute to honour

Dr M S M Ramzeen MBBS (University of Ceylon).

25 SEPTEMBER 1918 â 2011 (Jan)

OUR FATHER

My sister Hafeera and I lost a Great Man. âOur Fatherâ. As years were going by, he continuously smiled and said when asked, âHow are you daddy?â âWaiting for the Call!â The Call came on Jan 11 2011, 6.59 am. He looked peaceful and contended.

A simple, humble, inspiring, man, a great Physician always there, for our entire family members from infant, toddler, adolescence and adult.

My sister and I have memories from childhood, etched in our hearts, about his service to mankind, and no one has the right to doubt this, as we witnessed them with our own eyes.

A father who was our wise mentor and teacher, a thoughtful, kind-hearted, friendly, always empathetic to any situation, human being I have known.

Books he considered as âLifeblood of Mastermindâ. And, encouraged us to read at a very early age.

Books were precious. "Never step on a book. Never bend a page as a bookmark. Have a small little paper as bookmarkâ, he would say. His medical magazines were painstakingly filed in order of date, month and year. And, logically grouped and stored away neatly at Hafi's house, in the Book Cupboard.

During December School Holidays, at Shady Grove Avenue, our beautiful cottage home, he would treat us to the bookstore for Christmas Gifts. Yes Christmas Gifts! Our first classics Heidi, Bobsy Twins at the Seashore, Little Women, and Alice in Wonderland, bought at the tender age of 9 and 10, are still our favourites. Reading has to have âa dictionary by the side".....NO COMICs in the house!

School days were never ever hectic in our home. We were woken at 6 am and, "Be ready by 7am". Invariably, almost everyday, Daddy would do a house call to one of our family memberâs home, a baby, toddler, aunt or uncle was not well. So, we had to have our breakfast, a half boiled egg, and milk, hated it, but "Dadâs word was final". He was firm. "Finish your eggâ, and it was done. Then to the market to buy fresh beef, mutton or fish which was bought, taken back to the house, given to mother. This is how we start our day.

Never irritated, or annoyed about the lateness to work to his Surgery. Driving to school, in his Morris Minor, was enjoyable, and educational. He would point out the many traffic signs, and what it meant to interpret it correctly. He explained to us the lower gears, and the upper gears in a car, using the clutch. He would explain Traffic Police signals. Demonstrate the hand signals when a policeman was directing the road traffic.

Our secondary school subjects were more demanding, time consuming, and needed more help with studies. He was always, always, there for us no matter what.

Sunday day time was. âNo, Noâ to going out socializing anywhere! Maths work, took us the whole morning. He would give us about 15 to 20 maths problems, he would correct all the problems one by one, and taught us a step by step work pattern for maths. The work area requiring vertical line 2 inches on the right of the paper, while he washed the "Morris Minor" car, all by himself, carrying buckets of water, to the small garage of our home, while mother cooked s a tasty Sunday meal. This "mode" of teaching got me a Full Distinction, with ALL the answers correct for my Senior School Certificate (S.S.C) Examination at Ladies College, Colombo. My Dad was very proud of my achievement!

Sunday evening was a treat to the Galle Face Green, after my sister and I did the evening chores (no servants, we did the dusting, sweeping, taking away the dishes and washing up in our household). A relaxing evening in the car watching the sun "dip into the water", and both of us asking questions, where the sun went??? etc. A long family walk on the Galle Face Green, and then to ice cream at the Fountain CafÃ©, ended over Sunday evening.

April school holidays, a week in the mountains was fun, while driving up the mountain ranges, he would point out the mountains, the Bible Rock; Sardiel the bold outlaw of Ceylon, (the Robin Hood of Ceylon ârobbing from the rich and giving to the poorâ). The Outlawâs Hideaway, deep in the mountain range, relating a whole history about the man's life, and never forgetting to mention "the Hairpin Bends" on the way to Nuwara Eliya, the tea growing hill town.

He would always give preference to Mother. We would go to the cinema, screening 6pm a Tamil movie, after our homework was done. That is why my sister and I still enjoy Tamil movies and songs. As our preference was English Movies, he would never say No, if we ask him to take us to a 9.30 am English movie on a weekend.

Studies were number one priority for my sister and me. So Fasting during our exams was a NO!" This would come as a shock to many members of our family. My sister and I have achieved our goals because of his disciplinary methods.

My Dad would Fast and all 30 of them, working all day, till late in the night. Sometimes I did wonder how he did it, his many house calls, sleepless nights and early morning hours, starting at 5 am.

All these took a physical toll on him. But, he never complained. Always singing the song:

âQue Sera, Sera, Whatever will be, will be

The future's not ours, to see, Que Sera, Sera

What will be, will be."

Years rolled by. With both of us married, and then the Grandsons were born. His loving bond for his Grandsons was unshakeable, and unquestionable. In spite of his engaging work at the Surgery, he would take them for an early morning walk to the beach, a ride in the car around the block, and a treat of a whole slab of chocolate each and every day for the grandsons, when he comes home from his Surgery.

Even though he looked very tired coming home from work, the joy in his face when the grandsons cried out, âDada, Dada, you came!" as they run to the car as he drove down the drive way. So very patient he was with them that he would give the pen he was checking his accounts, during the morning when they bother him for it, and go to his room to get another pen.

All necessities, Food, Clothing for the children he provided. All meals for the house, he provided. And, never asked for a dime.

Never a harsh word to us, no spanking. A Special Kind of Discipline. His own, which has helped my sister and me to live life to the full! A Very Special Person to this Day Our Friend...Our Father.

Zulfi Azad.
